Award.AwardTitle: A workshop on Research Infrastructure in Support of NSF Surface Earth Processes Grand Challenges
Award.AbstractNarration:
A workshop will be convened to discuss infrastructure needs over the coming 5-10 years in support of Earth surface processes research. Understanding how Earth's terrestrial surface functions and evolves in response to changes in climate, sea level, vegetation, uplift/subsidence, and human influence is of broad importance, not least because this is where humans live. Research in this realm is underpinned by a range of infrastructure that includes instrumentation, experimental facilities, analytical capabilities, data and modeling resources, computing capacity, and more. Infrastructure needs evolve over time as new capabilities and new pressing questions emerge.

The workshop will bring together a diverse group of experts that spans the breadth of surface processes science to assess how the research community's needs will evolve in the coming decade. The workshop will draw on recent NRC and other prominent community documents to highlight the Grand Challenge science topics that would rely on this research infrastructure. The workshop outcomes will be discussed at major science meetings and a white paper and article will be produced to broadly disseminate the ideas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A workshop was held in October 2014 to develop an infrastructural vision to better equip the Surface Earth Processes community to address grand challenges articulated in several National Research Council reports as pressing questions to be addressed by this community: Are we approaching tipping points with regard to the interwoven physical, biological, geochemical, and human dynamics of Earth’s skin? What is the state of Earth’s Critical Zone? How can observed changes in Earth’s climate and biota help us make better decisions in the Anthropocene? The product of this effort was an article in the monthly newsletter EOS of the American Geophysical Union. The articulate advocates for three infrastucturally intensive initiatives: 1) a paleoenvironmental reconstruction program focused on extracting the archive of Earth response to abrupt change in the past as it exists in subsurface rocks on the continents; 2) an Earth Rover campaign to quantify water, sediment, and chemical fluxes as well as ecosystem function of the nation's "Critical Zone" (from the top of the forests to the base of the fractured bedrock zone that contains much of Earth's potable water), and 3) A distributed analytical and experimental laboratory network that would provid open access and sustainable support for analytical laboratories at various institutions around the country. These facilities would interact with the two aforementioned programs to ensure success and promote linkages.
